newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan central bank injects T$7.95 bln in funds.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan central bank injects T$7.95 bln in funds.

text.p: Taiwan's central bank, in reaction to an upswing in money rates, on Saturday injected T$7.95 billion worth of funds into the banking system through open market operations, a central bank official said.

The bank, contacted directly by interested financial institutions, purchased back T$7.95 billion in negotiable certificates of deposit offered by financial institutions with a single yield at 9.0 percent, the official said.
The institutions have the option of repurchasing the instruments within six days of their issue, the official said.

Taiwan's interbank rate soared into double digits to a record high close on Friday, creating tight liquidity in the banking system as funds continued to stream out of banks into the red-hot stock market.
The overnight interbank rate, capping a 10-session ascent, on Friday closed at 10.541 percent against Thursday's 8.597 finish -- roughly double the central bank's 5.0-5.5 percent target zone.
It was the rate's highest close since official recordings began on September 1, 1991.
The central bank said it would continue to watch closely the banking system's liquidity flow.
